explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Its autoignition point is 535degC (Hommel (1996)), which is above 70degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Its documented rat LD50 values include 400-1600 mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and 790 mg/kg bw (IUCLID (2000)), which fall under Category 4. The EU Risk Phrase for the substance is R22.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Its rabbit LD50 of 410 mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001)) falls under Category 3. The EU Risk Phrase for the substance is R21.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Since its rat LC50 is 13 mg/L/4h (3390 ppm) (IUCLID (2000)), and its EU Risk Phrase is R20 (EU-Annex 1 (accessed in October 2008)), the substance was classified into Category 4. Given that its saturated vapour pressure is 56.15 mg/L, the test was carried out in a vapour state with almost no included mists.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: In dermal route tests using six rabbits, dried skin was observed after 24 hours and encrustation was observed after 72 hours in all six treated animals, causing necrosis and thickening of the treated skin areas by strong irritation and corrosive effects. In addition, according to the test report, 5 of 6 treated animals showed signs of corrosive effects after 4-hour exposure (IUCLID (2000)). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Rabbit tests found that the substance is corrosive (IUCLID (2000)). In other rabbit tests, keratitis and symptoms associated with corneal epithelial tissues and fibrillary edema were observed, which were graded 8 (HSDB (2002)). In addition, since it represents Category 1 for skin corrosion / irritation, the substance was classified into Category 1.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Guinea pig maximization tests found that the substance is not sensitizing (IUCLID (2000)), indicating it represents the "Not classified" category. However, because these are List 2 studies and there are no other test results available, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of in vivo test results and in vitro mutagenicity test results using several indices. As additional notes, Ames tests (in vitro mutagenicity tests) gave negative results (IUCLID (2000)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In oral route tests using rats, since structure and composition of the liver and the structure and growth pattern of the skin were disrupted in the offspring (IUCLID (2000)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In oral administration tests using mice, depression of the central nervous system and sleepiness were noted (doses not given) (IUCLID (2000)). In addition, in oral administration tests via gavage using rats that were treated with 550, 790, or 950 mg/kg, of 6 of 10 rats survived in the group given 950 mg/kg, which falls under Category 2 guidance doses, 2 rats showed signs of encephalomalacia (HSDB (2002)). Furthermore, in inhalation tests using rats (4-hour exposure; doses: 5.4, 11.4, 12.5, and 21.9 mg/L), signs of ataxia and narcosis were observed at 12.5 mg/L, which falls under Category 2 guidance values (IUCLID (2000)). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 2 (central nervous system).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.rationale: In 28-day oral administration tests using rats, no serious toxic effects of administration were noted other than a slight increase in liver weight at the highest dose of 150 mg/kg/day (90-day correction value: approximately 47 mg/kg/day) (IUCLID (2000)). Similarly, in several 6-month inhalation exposure tests using rats (IUCLID (2000), PATTY (5th, 2001), HSDB (2002)), no effects of the test substance exposure were detected except for an increased liver weight seen in few animals. Although these tests did not detect any effects of the substance, test doses were set so low that the highest doses used were below the upper limit of the range of Category 2 guidance values. Due to low doses tested, classification is not possible based on these tests.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96-hour LC50 = 897 mg/L for fish (fathead minnow) (ECOTOX, 2008), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it is water soluble (water solubility = 1000000 mg/L (SRC, 2005), and its classification for acute toxicity is the "Not classified" category, the substance was categorized into "Not classified".
